title: Uber Survived the Spying Scandal. Their Careers Didn’t.
content: A former co-worker accused the men of wiretapping their colleagues, hacking foreign governments and stealing trade secrets. It wasn’t true, but the allegations still follow them.

title: Inside the ‘Misinformation’ Wars
content: Journalists and academics are developing a new language for truth. The results are not always clearer.

title: Wall Street Grudgingly Allows Remote Work as Bankers Dig In
content: Finance employees who couldn’t imagine working from home before the pandemic are now reluctant to return to the office. Their bosses can’t figure out how to bring them back.

title: As U.K. Beckons Truck Drivers, Many in Poland Say ‘No Thanks’
content: A special visa offer, aimed at forestalling a supply chain fiasco during the holidays, goes begging for takers.

title: It’s Beginning to Look a Lot Like Hanukkah
content: What’s that reindeer doing with menorah antlers? Retailers want inclusive holiday merchandise, but hit a few snags.

title: Local News Outlets Could Reap $1.7 Billion in Build Back Better Aid
content: A small paper like The Storm Lake Times in Iowa would receive a big tax credit. So would Gannett, the nation’s largest news publisher.

title: North Carolina’s Furniture Hub Is Booming. What Comes Next?
content: The furniture capital of the state is ground zero for inflation, labor shortages, hot demand and limited supply. It’s debating how to cope.

title: The Holiday Shopping Season Is Here, but Is It Back?
content: Shoppers are returning to stores in much bigger numbers than last year, but the atmosphere is not quite as carefree as the prepandemic days of 2019.

title: A ‘Simpsons’ Episode Lampooned Chinese Censorship. In Hong Kong, It Vanished.
content: The episode mocked both Mao Zedong and the government’s efforts to suppress memory of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

title: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
content: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.

title: Europe Revisits Nuclear Power as Climate Deadlines Loom
content: While wind and solar ramp up, several countries, including France and Britain, are looking to expand their nuclear energy programs. Germany and others aren’t so enthusiastic.

title: Could Roads Recharge Electric Cars? The Technology May Be Close.
content: But challenges await, including technical issues, regulatory barriers and many miles of highway.

content: After tumbling on Friday, European markets were higher and oil prices gained.

title: An Auto Show for the Raddest Cars of the ’80s and ’90s
content: Nostalgia mixes with tape decks and car phones at RADwood events that aim to capture “the essence of a bodacious era.”

content: Americans born after 1980 have been wrestling with sharp price increases for the first time since they’ve been old enough to notice.

title: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
content: No simultaneous streaming: “Encanto” or “House of Gucci” could only be seen in theaters this weekend. Even still, some viewers stayed home.

title: Sylvia Weinstock, the ‘da Vinci of Wedding Cakes,’ Dies at 91
content: She produced floral-draped architectural works in the shape of rose-studded topiaries, baskets of speckled lilies and bouquets of anemones.

title: The Week in Business: Choosing the Same Path
content: President Biden opted for continuity at the Fed, nominating Jerome Powell to a second four-year term. And it’s that time of year — for travel and shopping.

title: As Covid Infections Spread, Nursing Homes Lag Behind on the Rollout for Booster Shots
content: Thousands of new cases have been reported among vulnerable elderly residents in the last several months, as the virulent Delta variant fuels outbreaks.

title: What Will the World Be Like in 20 Years?
content: Looking at demographic data can help us assess the opportunities and challenges of the coming decades.

content: The federal government recently lifted most visitation restrictions at nursing homes. But concerns linger that a full reopening could leave residents vulnerable to another coronavirus surge.

title: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.

title: Robberies are becoming an increasing concern for retailers.
content: About 69 percent of stores said they have seen an increase in organized theft in the past year.

content: Stocks and oil futures slumped, while investors sought safety in government bonds.

title: How Black Friday got its name.
content: Historians say the Philadelphia police took to calling the day before the annual Army-Navy football game Black Friday because officers had to work long hours and deal with bad traffic, bad weather and other miseries.

title: In Europe, trying to find fun and games in holiday retailing.
content: Black Friday discounts are now routine for European toy stores and other retailers, but pandemic restrictions remain a big presence in some areas.

title: Time, Money and Chicken Fat: A Guide to Inflation-Proof Gift-Giving
content: Prices are soaring for almost everything, but a few choice gifts are even cheaper than two years ago. Or show your love by going on your family’s annual “lard run.”

content: Holiday shopping over the past 80 years as chronicled in photos from The New York Times archives.

title: The Car Key of the Future (Is Still in Your Pocket)
content: They’re in fobs or on phones, and digital or “smart,” and they can do far more than just open doors and start the engine.
